CONCEPT.SN: Use for versions of a work shortened by condensation and omission but retaining the general meaning and manner of presentation of the original.
CONCEPT.BT: Versions of works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for addresses delivered at educational institutions.
Use for publications issued by an educational institution listing course offerings, calendars, and programs.

Use for formal written treatises presenting the author’s scholarly investigation or original research on a specialized subject, usually submitted to a university as the final requirement for an advanced academic degree or diploma and for European academic dissertations from previous centuries, in which the content of the dissertation was written by the Praeses or primary professor and defended by the Respondent or degree candidate.

CONCEPT.CM: Specialized collections may wish to subdivide by specific types, e.g., "Account books $x Ledgers."
CONCEPT.SN: Use for books in which details of financial transactions are recorded.
Use for nursery rhymes in which the phrases repeat and build up as the verse progresses.

Use for a series of lines or verses in which a set or sets of letters, such as the initial or final letters of the lines, form a word, phrase, sentence, or regular alphabetic sequence when read in order.
CONCEPT.BT: Literary forms (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for plays with extensive printed production information.
CONCEPT.BT: Versions of works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for works that are modifications of other works, having been edited or rewritten for a different purpose, use, or audience, or expressed through an artistic medium other than the original.
CONCEPT.BT: Versions of works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for formal written or spoken speeches directed to a specific audience.
Used for rules having the force of law issued by a governmental agency to interpret or implement a statute.

CONCEPT.BT: Purpose of work (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for cards distributed by merchants or manufacturers to advertise or promote their business or product, common beginning in the late 19th century.
Use for sworn statements in writing made voluntarily under oath before an authorized official.
Use for bound volumes in which collections of materials such as stamps, photographs, or autographs may be assembled and displayed.

CONCEPT.HN: SN and added BT and Hierarchy of illustrated works added 1/08
CONCEPT.SN: Use for literary or visual representations of abstract ideas or principles through characters, figures, or events.
CONCEPT.BT: Literary forms (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for works containing a calendar of days, weeks, and months, together with information such as astronomical data, various statistics, etc. Do not use for modern factual compendia such as the World Almanac.

CONCEPT.HN: Changed 1/91. Formerly, "Alphabet books" may have been indexed as "Alphabets (Primers)."
CONCEPT.SN: Use for both alphabet books meant as primers for teaching the alphabet and those intended as vehicles for an illustrator’s art.
Use for works consisting of short rhymes for teaching the alphabet.
Use for teaching devices, whether individual or in books, consisting of a circular wheel bearing alphabet letters mounted beneath a sheet with a cut-out.
CONCEPT.BT: Instructional works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for works published openly as contrasts to the mainstream political, social, and cultural press of their time.
CONCEPT.BT: Conditions of publication (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for words or phrases formed by rearranging letters of other words or phrases.
Use for volumes of illustrations that visualize the structure and/or systems of a living body.
Use for books containing anatomical illustrations that, through the use of movable flaps, provide layered images of the body.
Use for historical records arranged year by year.
Use for sermons delivered on the annual recurrence of a date in order to commemorate a particular occasion or event associated with that date.
Use for publications issued yearly summarizing the administrative, operational and financial activities of a business, organization, or institution during the preceding year.
Use for a volume of collected writings focusing on a particular literary genre or other organizing concept such as subject, region, class of author, or time period.
CONCEPT.BT: Conditions of publication (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.HN: Approved term, June 2010; Candidate term, June 2010
CONCEPT.SN: Use for letters composed of fancifully-manipulated human figures.
Use for literature written in opposition to the movement to abolish slavery.
Use for literature that posits a negative sentiment of Catholicism and/or its proponents and practitioners.
Use for literature that posits a negative sentiment of the Christian clergy.
Use for literature that posits a negative sentiment of communism and/or its proponents and practitioners.
Use for literature that posits a negative sentiment of homosexuals and homosexuality.
Use for literature that posits a negative sentiment of immigrants or immigration.
Use for literature that posits a negative sentiment of Freemasons or Freemasonry.
Use for literature that posits a negative sentiment of Jews or Judaism.
Use for literature written in opposition to the slave trade.
Use for literature written in opposition to woman suffrage.
CONCEPT.BT: Content of work (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for works containing both text and music for the Daily Office, Matins or Lauds through Compline)
Use for literature written in opposition to slavery.
Use for sermons that address the final doom or ultimate destiny of the world as described in the Bible.

CONCEPT.HN: 1991 term added. 2/97 "Engagement books" added as UF.

CONCEPT.SN: Use for books containing depictions of coats of arms.
Use for sermons delivered on the occasion of an election within an artillery company, often addressing the religious implications of war.
Use for books intended as works of art in themselves and designed as an artistic whole, integrating binding, text, illustration, etc. Do not use for "Livres d'artistes."

CONCEPT.HN: This term appeared in the 1983 edition of this thesaurus without parenthetical qualifiers; no longer approved without qualifiers, see below.
CONCEPT.SN: Deleted term. Do not use.

CONCEPT.HN: Changed 1/91. Formerly, "Atlases (Geographic)" may have been indexed as "Atlases."
CONCEPT.SN: Use for collections of maps in book form.

CONCEPT.HN: Changed 1/91. Formerly, "Atlases (Scientific)" may have been indexed as "Atlases."
CONCEPT.SN: Use for comprehensive, systematically arranged collections of plates, charts, etc. that illustrate a scientific or technical subject.
Use for a list of items to be sold by auction, typically arranged by lot, containing descriptive details and estimated bids for each lot.
Gathering term; do not use; index under a narrower term.
Use for narratives in which a person presents an account of his or her life.
Use for volumes containing leaves on which the owner collects autographs, with or without accompanying inscriptions, quotations, or drawings.
Use for speeches given to a graduating class of an educational institution at services traditionally held prior to the commencement ceremony.
Use for sermons given to a graduating class of an educational institution at services traditionally held prior to the commencement ceremony.

Use for 18th-century English comic or farcical plays in which traditional or popular melodies, refitted with new lyrics, are integrated into the dramatic structure of the play and alternate with dialogue.

Use for traditional popular poems of Europe and North America, often set to music, combining narrative, dramatic dialogue, and lyrical passages, and having a meter, rhyming pattern, and recurring refrain.
CONCEPT.BT: Literary forms (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.HN: Changed 1/91. Formerly, "Banned works" may have been indexed as "Banned books."
CONCEPT.SN: Use for works which have been officially prohibited from distribution or sale by a legal authority, civil or ecclesiastical.

Use for official church registers that record the names, dates, and other significant information documenting the admission of an individual into the Christian community through baptism, that is, the application of water as a symbol of purification and regeneration.
CONCEPT.BT: Religious works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for sermons that address the moral and religious implications of conflict by focusing on a particular battle or military encounter.
Use for poems which directly or indirectly ask for remuneration.
Use for paraphrases in story form of Biblical texts.
CONCEPT.BT: Religious works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for small, thick, heavily illustrated books, usually containing texts abridged from popular fiction.
CONCEPT.BT: Conditions of publication (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.HN: Form of term changed from Bildungsromane; SN and UFs added, changes approved 20100115
CONCEPT.SN: Use for novels in which the theme is the development of a character from youth to adulthood.
Use for proposals for legislation.

Use for periodically published official records of the deaths in a given locality, often including causes of death and usually in broadside form. Having originated in London in the 16th century, some of these records eventually included other vital statistics such as christenings and marriages.
Use for books with hidden nicks or tabs in the fore-edge so that different illustrations appear on different occasions of riffling.
CONCEPT.BT: Conditions of publication (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for auction catalogs in which a majority of the items listed are books.

Use for printed descriptions or accounts, sometimes incorporating sample text or specimen pages, issued separately or as part of books or periodicals, to solicit subscription, purchase, or other patronage of forthcoming books.
Use for unattached devices intended to be inserted between leaves in a book as a place marker.
Use for works printed in a way that enhances their readability for people with impaired vision.
CONCEPT.BT: Versions of works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for prayer books modelled on the Breviary, and containing a calendar, the Little Office of the Virgin Mary, the Office for the Dead, and miscellaneous prayers.
Use for books issued by advertisers, the contents of which are not primarily advertising matter.
Use this term rather than "Publishers' advertisements" for examples appearing before the roles of bookseller and publisher were clearly differentiated.
Use this term rather than "Publishers' catalogs" for examples appearing before the roles of bookseller and publisher were clearly differentiated.

CONCEPT.HN: Form of UF term changed from Bowdlerized books, 12/2011.

CONCEPT.SN: Use for books containing illustrations of livestock brands.
Use for works containing solely text of all that is said or sung at the Daily Office, Matins or Lauds through Compline.
Use for poems printed on one side only of a sheet of paper intended to be read unfolded.

Use for separately published pieces of paper or other material, printed and intended to be read unfolded; usually intended to be posted, publicly distributed, or sold, e.g., proclamations, handbills, ballad sheets, newssheets.
Use for literary or dramatic travesties characterized by ludicrously extravagant incongruity between a subject and its treatment.
CONCEPT.BT: Humorous works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for satirical broadside poems, usually in the form of mock epitaphs, illustrated with skeleton caricatures and issued around the Day of the Dead.
CONCEPT.UF: Day of the Dead broadside poems

CONCEPT.SN: Use for tabular registers of days, not for lists of manuscripts or documents; subdivide by date.
Use for biographies of political candidates issued at the time of their campaigns.
Use for materials printed to win support of voters.
Use for first person accounts of the experiences of people captured and held against their will.

Use for verbal or visual works which portray in a critical or facetious way a real individual or group, or a figure representing a social, political, ethnic, or racial type. The effect is usually achieved through distortion or exaggeration of some characteristic or characteristics.
CONCEPT.BT: Humorous works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for collections of the texts of festive songs, usually related to Christmas.
Use for verses in broadside or pamphlet form presented to patrons by newspaper carriers, around the start of the New Year, often to request a gratuity.
Use for pictorial images executed in an exaggerated or abbreviated manner intended as satire, caricature, or humor.
CONCEPT.BT: Humorous works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for lists associating specific performers with their parts.

CONCEPT.CM:
Although Webster's 3rd New International Dictionary of the English Language (the authoritative dictionary for the RBMS thesauri) lists "catalogue" as merely an alternate spelling to "catalog," and although the shared cataloging code used by the English-speaking world is entitled Anglo-American Cataloguing Rules, the former has increasingly come to be viewed as a British spelling. More to the point, all of the other thesauri with which we have agreed to cooperate both in resolving existing conflicts and preventing future conflicts use the spelling "catalogs."
We realize this change introduces some ironies, particularly that of putting the spelling of the term within the thesaurus at variance with the spelling of the term on the title-pages of the thesauri. Nevertheless, we think that this is a change that has to be made, barring the wholehearted re-embrace of the "ue" by Americans, and fear that the longer we wait, the greater the conflict between RBMS thesaurus terms and other thesaurus terms commonly used in the cataloging of American libraries.
CONCEPT.SN: Use for a list of items, arranged methodically, containing descriptive details for each item.
CONCEPT.BT: Purpose of work (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for illustrated broadsides on themes of popular appeal, printed from wood or metal cuts and sold cheaply.
Use for works that provide instruction on principles of doctrines, especially religious doctrines, typically structured as a series of questions and answers.
CONCEPT.BT: Instructional works (Gathering term; do not assign)
Religious works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for collections of maps that show the relative positions of known celestial bodies such as stars, moons, planets, etc.

CONCEPT.HN: Changed 1/91. Formerly, "Censored works" may have been indexed as "Censored books" or as "Prohibited books."
CONCEPT.SN: Use for works that have been altered, prohibited, or suppressed because of allegedly objectionable content.
CONCEPT.BT: Conditions of publication (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for official counts and statistical analyses of the living population of a species (human or nonhuman) in a given geographic area (city, county, state, province, country, etc.) taken at a particular point in time.
Use for sermons given to commemorate a centennial anniversary.
Use for documents containing certified statements of ownership, membership, fulfilled requirements, legal status, etc.
Use for musical compositions that consist of rhythmic and usually repetitive words or vocal sounds.
Use for small, inexpensively printed books or pamphlets sold primarily by traveling peddlers beginning in the 17th century. Do not use for 20th century items which represent themselves as chapbooks.
CONCEPT.BT: Conditions of publication (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for collections of puzzles and conundrums in which words, phrases, concepts, short dramatic scenes, etc. are meant to be conveyed by brief enigmatic rhymes or by means of pantomime, to be interpreted by listeners or onlookers.
Use for written documents, issued by governing bodies, which grant rights to individuals or establish legal entities or boundaries.
Use for sermons addressed to children.
Use for large books with the various parts of a musical composition displayed in a single opening so as to be used simultaneously by all sections of a choir.
Use for collections of excerpts from original texts used as teaching specimens of a literature or language.
Use for books containing the names of those individuals in attendance at the christening of a given individual.
CONCEPT.BT: Religious works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for the style of British theater, often performed at Christmas, which dramatizes a fairy tale or nursery story and features songs, dance, topical jokes, buffoonery, etc., with leading characters played by members of the opposite sex.
Use for sermons that address the meaning of Christmas or are given during the Christmas season.
Use for histories in which events are described in chronological order. These differ from annals in being more connected and full.
Use for systematically arranged names, addresses, and other identifying data of inhabitants and/or organizations of a city or cities.
Use for notes taken during course sessions. Do not use for biographical sketches and updates of alumni.
Use for partial, full, or multiple pages of text or illustrations that have been removed from their original source.
Use for bound volumes of line drawings meant to be filled in with crayon, watercolor, pencil, etc.
Use for dramatic works that are light, often humorous or satirical, usually having a happy ending.
CONCEPT.BT: Humorous works (Gathering term; do not assign)
Humorous works (Gathering term; do not assign)
Humorous works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Gathering term; do not use; index under a narrower term.
CONCEPT.BT: Purpose of work (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for speeches given to students as part of a graduation ceremony at an educational institution.

CONCEPT.HN: Proposed by Richard Noble; term approved 1/2006
CONCEPT.SN: Use for poems, generally appearing in the preliminaries of books, written in praise of the author and the work
Use for personal notebooks in which the owner has copied passages of interest or written his or her own compositions; use also for printed versions of such works.
Use for formal summaries of proposed commercial ventures distributed to prospective investors or participants.
Use for agreements made between the Pope and a sovereign or government for the regulation of ecclesiastical matters.

Use for poems which embody the concepts of the concrete poetry movement of the 1950s and 1960s, in which orthographic elements are arranged freely, not necessarily in linear syntax, and meaning is derived from spatial, pictorial, or typographic characteristics of the work, as well as from the sense of the words.

CONCEPT.HN: Changed 1/91. Formerly, "Condemned works" may have been indexed as "Condemned books."
CONCEPT.SN: Use for works deemed unacceptable reading by a religious or other group.

CONCEPT.DESCRIPTOR: Conditions of publication (Gathering term; do not assign)
CONCEPT.SN: Gathering term; do not use; index under a narrower term.

Use for documents that provide essential information about a conference, such as title, purpose, date, time, venue, names of speakers, topics to be discussed during the conference, and schedule of presentations and other events.
Use for autobiographies dealing with highly private matters, usually with some theoretical, intellectual, or spiritual emphasis.
Use for formal written or spoken speeches directed to the United States Congress.
Use for a document embodying the fundamental governing principles or laws of a nation, state, society, or other organization.

CONCEPT.DESCRIPTOR: Content of work (Gathering term; do not assign)
CONCEPT.SN: Gathering term; do not use; index under a narrower term.
CONCEPT.NT: Religious works (Gathering term; do not assign)
Social customs (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for legally binding agreements between two or more parties.
Use for accounts, often autobiographical, of individuals adopting a new faith following a revelatory experience.
CONCEPT.BT: Religious works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for texts of speeches made, or purported to have been made, by those convicted of a crime.
Use for publications containing collections of food recipes or instructions for preparing food.
CONCEPT.BT: Instructional works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for penmanship or calligraphy manuals which include instructional text and examples as well as blank areas designed for a pupil’s practice writing. For works which do not contain such blank areas for practice, use "Penmanship manuals."
Use for single-leaf forerunners of newspapers. For similar items consisting of more than one leaf, use "Newsbooks."

CONCEPT.HN: Changed 6/2016. Formerly, "Correspondence" may have been indexed as "Letters."

CONCEPT.SN: Use for books outlining the education, conduct, duties, and training of noble or royal persons, or persons serving at court.
CONCEPT.BT: Social customs (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for works featuring illustrations of peddlers hawking their wares, usually with the text of the rhyme they cried.
Use for pictorial publications, usually amateur in nature, documenting a voyage of a particular ship and distributed to the ship’s crew.

CONCEPT.HN: Changed 7/2016. Formerly, "Cryptograms" may have been indexed as "Ciphers."
CONCEPT.SN: Use for texts, the meaning of which is concealed by substitution or transposition of letters or numbers.
CONCEPT.BT: Content of work (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for literary or visual representations of a dance or procession in which death as a skeleton leads its victim to the grave.
CONCEPT.BT: Literary forms (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.NON-DESCRIPTOR: Day of the Dead broadside poems

CONCEPT.SN: Use for account books of original entry which record the various transactions of the day in the order in which they occurred. For works sometimes known as daybooks which are diaries rather than account books use "Diaries."
Use for sermons given as part of a ceremony of dedication.
Use for calendars which highlight religious activities and events for specific days; not for calendars which are only illustrated with religious pictures.
Use for texts intended to aid prayer, worship, or spiritual contemplation.
CONCEPT.BT: Religious works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for works constructed in the form of conversation between two or more people.

Use for personal accounts of events, experiences, feelings, and observations, usually recorded daily in a calendar, notebook, or other type of blank book. Can also be used for the blank books specially organized for keeping a daily record, or having spaces with printed dates for daily memoranda and jottings.

Use for reference works comprising lists of words, arranged alphabetically or thematically, that provide information for each word, such as spelling, meaning, etymology, usage, or equivalents in other languages.

Use for melodramatic fiction featuring romance and adventure published as cheap paperbacks in the United States from the late 19th century into the early 20th century. For the British equivalent, use Penny dreadfuls.

CONCEPT.HN: Changed 09/2015. Formerly "Direct mail" may have been indexed as "Advertising mail."
CONCEPT.SN: Use for printed matter soliciting trade or contributions, sent directly through the mail to large groups of potential customers or contributors.
Use for systematically arranged lists of names, addresses, and other identifying data of people and/or organizations.
Gathering term; do not use; index under a narrower term.
CONCEPT.BT: Purpose of work (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for lists recording the names of members of a deliberative body at the time of a vote, divided according to the position taken by each voter.
Use for works proclaiming the imminent approach of the end of the world.
Use for poems in the form of monologues.
Use for books on how to draw.
Use for short poems on rural or pastoral themes, traditionally in the form of a dialogue between shepherds.
Use for sermons delivered on the occasion of an election.
Use for poems or songs written as a lament, usually for a person who has died, or as a general meditation on mortality.

Use for collections of emblems, i.e., mottoes or epigrams accompanied by a verse and sometimes a symbolic illustration, based upon a poetic conceit or moral statement, particularly popular in the 16th and 17th centuries.
CONCEPT.BT: Literary forms (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for works giving detailed information useful to those emigrating or resettling.

Use for general works containing articles on subjects spanning all branches of knowledge, or for specialized works containing comprehensive information on one particular area of knowledge, frequently arranged in alphabetical order.
Use for transient everyday items, usually printed on paper, that are produced for a specific limited use and then often thrown away.
CONCEPT.BT: Conditions of publication (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for works giving the computed positions of celestial bodies for each day or other regular interval; used by navigators and astronomers.
Use for long narrative poems on the adventures and deeds of one or more heroic characters.
Use for short satiric poems or any similar pointed sayings.
CONCEPT.BT: Humorous works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.HN: Changed 1/91. Formerly, "Epistolary novels" may have been indexed as "Epistolary fiction."

Use for literary or artistic works focused on sexual love or desire.
CONCEPT.BT: Literary forms (Gathering term; do not assign)
Literary forms (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for didactic works on the behavior, decorum, and manners of polite society.
CONCEPT.BT: Social customs (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for dictionaries which provide a detailed, linguistic history and evolution of words in a given language.
Use for tributes written in praise of a person or thing, especially in honor of a deceased person.

CONCEPT.HN: Changed 1983. Change from "Evangelistaries" to "Evangeliaries." Formerly, "Evangeliaries" may have been indexed as "Evangelistaries."
CONCEPT.SN: Use for works containing readings from the Gospels used principally at the Mass throughout the year.
Use for sermons delivered prior to the execution of criminals.
Use for books containing only blank, usually ruled pages, intended for a pupil’s practice penmanship or calligraphy.
Use for publications that document and provide context for works or objects displayed in an exhibition.

CONCEPT.HN: Changed 1/91. Formerly, "Expurgated editions" may have been indexed as "Expurgated books." SN added 12/2011.
CONCEPT.SN: Use for editions of a work in which objectionable parts of the original text have been omitted or altered, usually on moral grounds. This term applies to all copies of an edition, not to individual copies that have been altered.
CONCEPT.BT: Versions of works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for short didactic tales that feature animals, humans, gods, and even inanimate objects as characters to teach a lesson.
CONCEPT.BT: Instructional works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for bawdily humorous metrical tales of a type found chiefly in 12th and 13th century French poetry.
CONCEPT.BT: Humorous works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for literary works characterized by coarse or obscene wit.
CONCEPT.BT: Humorous works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for tales, typically told to children, containing elements of folklore that often have fantastic or supernatural aspects.

CONCEPT.HN: Changed 1/91. Formerly, "Family histories" may have been indexed as "Genealogies."
CONCEPT.SN: Use for narrative family histories. For family trees and other genealogical listings of family members, use "Genealogies."

Use for highly imaginative fiction, often featuring imaginary worlds, extraordinary creatures or magic, in which the action occurs in an unreal time and/or place, or is not constrained by the limitations of conventional reality.

CONCEPT.HN: 1/05 Scope note added to existing term; edited 6/06.
CONCEPT.SN: Use for independent, self-published periodicals issued by or for enthusiasts of aspects of popular culture and entertainment, usually inexpensively produced and with small circulation.
Use for comic plays featuring contrived and ludicrous situations, exaggerated characterizations, and physical humor.
Use for final sermons delivered by a pastor upon terminating his/her ministry to a congregation.

CONCEPT.HN: 1/99 Changed existing term from "Fast day sermons" to "Fast-day sermons". Add SN and UF to existing term.
CONCEPT.SN: Use for texts of sermons given on days designated as days of fasting.
Use for formal written or spoken speeches given on a designated day of fasting and prayer.
Use for official announcements, made by a legal authority, declaring a day of fasting and prayer.
Use for sermons given on designated days of religious celebration in honor of a deity or saint.
Use for accounts of festivals, parades, ceremonial entries, and the like.
CONCEPT.BT: Social customs (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for a collection of writings contributed by colleagues, associates, and former students to honor a person or institution.
Use for serialized fiction in the form of novels or periodical literature.
CONCEPT.BT: Conditions of publication (Gathering term; do not assign)
Literary forms (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for books containing a series of images bound together in sequence so that an illusion of movement can be imparted by flipping them rapidly.
Use for traditional plays, usually performed in rural communities at certain festive times of the year by local residents.
Use for short narratives rooted in traditional oral culture.

CONCEPT.HN: In the 1983 edition, this was an approved term.
CONCEPT.SN: Gathering term; do not use; index under a narrower term.
CONCEPT.BT: Content of work (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for reference works detailing prescribed forms, procedures, or models according to which something is to be done.

CONCEPT.HN: Changed 1/91. Formerly, "Fourth of July addresses" may have been indexed as "Fourth of July orations."

CONCEPT.BT: Social customs (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for works which recount aspects of funeral and memorial activities relating chiefly to royalty, nobility, or famous persons, usually illustrated and containing some description of mausoleums, caskets, church decorations, funeral guests, etc. May include accounts of sermons, eulogies, etc.
CONCEPT.BT: Social customs (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for materials designed for play, usually according to prescribed rules.
Use for family trees and other listings of family members. For narrative histories, use "Family histories."
Gathering term; do not use; index under a narrower term.
CONCEPT.BT: Content of work (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for works popular in the 11th-14th centuries, often metrical, chronicling the deeds and adventures of an individual or of important historic events.

CONCEPT.HN: 1983 Remove from "Commemorative works" hierarchy; change scope note. Prior to 1997 was a NT of "Commemorative works."
CONCEPT.SN: Use for illustrated literary miscellanies, popular in the 19th century, intended to be given as gifts and often published annually.
CONCEPT.BT: Purpose of work (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for works containing the full texts of the four canonical Gospels.
CONCEPT.BT: Religious works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.HN: Changed 1/91. Formerly, "Gothic novels" may have been indexed as "Gothic fiction."

CONCEPT.SN: Use for works containing the musical portion of the Mass sung by the choir.
Use for books in which people attending an event or visiting a location write their names and sentiments.
Use for works that provide information about locations (countries, districts, towns, buildings, etc.), particular sites or objects of interest.
Use for sermons given to commemorate a fifty-year anniversary.
Use for the section of pantomimes typically featuring a combination of the stock characters Harlequin, Clown, Pantaloon, and Columbine.
Use for works, often illustrated, containing names, descriptions, and medicinal uses of plants.

Use for tragic or tragicomedic plays of a style originating in the English Restoration period, written in rhymed couplets, observing strictly the unities of time, place, and action, and typically focusing on themes of love and honor.
Use for literary works in prose whose narratives are set in a particular place and period of history, sometimes featuring characters based completely or partially on historical figures.
Gathering term; do not use; index under a narrower term.
CONCEPT.BT: Content of work (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for plays based on historic events or well-known historical figures often from the medieval or early modern past.

CONCEPT.HN:
Scope note changed 6/2012. Scope note formerly read: Although some authorities attempt to distinguish "Hornbooks" and "Battledores" by type of material used or by date produced, no consistent distinction in usage has been documented.
UF Battledores deleted 6/2012.
CONCEPT.SN: Use for hand-held teaching devices typically consisting of a piece of parchment or paper protected by a sheet of transparent horn and mounted to a thin wooden board with a handle.

CONCEPT.DESCRIPTOR: Humorous works (Gathering term; do not assign)
CONCEPT.SN: Gathering term; do not use; index under a narrower term.
CONCEPT.BT: Purpose of work (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for volumes containing a collection of hymns.
Use for songs of worship or praise, particularly to be sung at religious services.
CONCEPT.BT: Religious works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for narratives structured in the form of dialogues consisting of the imagined speech of real people.

Use for works popular in the 17th and 18th centuries that combine elements of documentary travel accounts with the creation of a fictional voyage of discovery, exploration, and conquest by a European traveler, allowing for satire and parody.
Use for materials printed before 1501 with movable metal type.
CONCEPT.BT: Conditions of publication (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for lists, usually alphabetical, of names, places, subjects, etc. mentioned or discussed in a text, with an indication, usually by page number, of their location within the text. For printed or drawn symbols of a hand with an extended index finger pointing out a passage in a text, use Manicules. For Index librorum prohibitorum, or lists of works deemed unacceptable reading by a religious or other group, see Condemned works.
Use for ecclesiastical documents certifying official cancellation of all or part of the temporal punishment due for sins.
CONCEPT.BT: Religious works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for official documents concerning the nature, extent, and value of a deceased landholder's possessions.
Use for sermons preached at the installation of a person in a religious office or parish, whether delivered by that person or another.

CONCEPT.DESCRIPTOR: Instructional works (Gathering term; do not assign)
CONCEPT.SN: Gathering term; do not use; index under a narrower term.
CONCEPT.BT: Purpose of work (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for works of language instruction in which the text is interlined in a second language.
CONCEPT.BT: Instructional works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for transcripts or recordings of conversations in which one or more persons question, consult, or evaluate another person or group of people.
Use for printed or handwritten requests for one’s presence at an event.
Use for documents outlining a planned route of travel and sometimes including scheduled events.

Use for collections of short humorous anecdotes or prose tales of a style popular during the 15th through the 18th century, often with such additions as brief poems, riddles, epitaphs, or witticisms, and typically cheaply printed.
CONCEPT.BT: Humorous works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for reports of Jesuit missionaries on their travels and activities, especially in the Americas and Asia.
CONCEPT.BT: Religious works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for works written for children.
CONCEPT.BT: Literary forms (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for works produced by children and young people.
Use for works produced to mark the occasion of a gathering or event, distributed to those in attendance and not usually otherwise available. For 19th century gift books, use "Gift books."
Use for notes made in the course of scientific inquiry conducted in a controlled environment.
Use for comic or satiric attacks on persons.

CONCEPT.HN: Approved 06/2016. Formerly, "Largeprint books" was a non-postable reference for "Books for the visually impaired."
CONCEPT.SN: Use for books set in a type size larger than normal for the benefit of people with impaired vision.
Use for a book containing an account of an earlier printed book or manuscript and including an original leaf or leaves from it.
CONCEPT.BT: Content of work (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for notes prepared for a lecture by a speaker, or notes taken on a lecture by an attendee.
CONCEPT.BT: Instructional works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for speeches or presentations on a given subject delivered before an audience or class, especially for purposes of instruction.
Use for collections of prescribed forms, procedures, or models according to which legal documents are to be written.

Use for documents expressing legal acts or agreements, or defining or evidencing rights, obligations, entitlements, or liabilities, such as contracts, wills, deeds, mortgages, share certificates, etc. May be subdivided by type of instrument, using the standard terms of the jurisdiction involved.
Use for formal written requests submitted to a court asking for redress of an injustice.

CONCEPT.BT: Content of work (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for documents containing the text of speeches given before a legislative body.
Use for documents containing the texts of proceedings in which legislators or their designees receive testimony about legislation that might be enacted.
Use for documents that record the activities, events, and transactions of a legislative body.
Use for comprehensive or selected lists issued by a library or group of libraries of the books, periodicals, maps, and other materials in their collections, arranged in systematic order.

CONCEPT.HN: Form changed from Libretti to Librettos, and SN added 6/2012.
CONCEPT.SN: Use for the texts of operas, oratorios, or other extended vocal compositions, without musical notation.

Use for volumes consisting of autographs, inscriptions, quotations, drawings, or other mementos, contributed by fellow students or scholars met during the owner’s studies and travels, especially popular in Germany and the Low Countries from the 16th through the 19th centuries.
Humorous poems consisting of five lines with an a/a/b/b/a rhyme scheme and typically a rigid meter.
Use for liturgical prayers consisting of a series of invocations and supplications with alternate responses between a leader and congregation.
CONCEPT.BT: Religious works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.HN: Changed 7/2015 from non-postable term (was Use Literary hoaxes).
CONCEPT.SN: Use for writings created or altered in fraudulent imitation of an author.

CONCEPT.DESCRIPTOR: Literary forms (Gathering term; do not assign)
CONCEPT.SN: Gathering term; do not use; index under a narrower term.
Use for writings that are created as deliberate attempts to dupe, deceive, or trick persons into believing the reality or truth of evidence or assertions that are not true or real.
Use for literature that expresses a negative sentiment toward a particular group of society, especially for reasons based on religion, race, gender, creed, or national origin.
Use for periodicals of the type which first appeared at the end of the 19th century devoted to poetry or avant-garde thinking and usually of limited circulation.
Use for collections of official texts of liturgical services for use in public worship, such as the Anglican Book of Common Prayer, or the Jewish Siddur.

Use for books containing original works of graphic art, usually produced separately from text and binding. In general, "Livres d'artistes" denotes books containing original graphic art; "Artists' books" denotes books viewed as the works of art themselves.

CONCEPT.BT: Social customs (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for records in which the daily activities of an expedition, voyage, mission, or other undertaking are noted chronologically as a matter of record, usually by the person in command or a designated person, with the date included in each entry.
Use for short poems expressing the emotions or state of mind of the poet or another speaker, originally intended for musical accompaniment.

Use for books containing rules, guidelines, or instructions needed to perform tasks, operations, processes, occupations, arts, or studies, and intended to be used as a reference while the task or study is performed.
CONCEPT.BT: Instructional works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for lists of materials or products for sale by a manufacturer, usually with description and price information.

Use for representations, normally to scale and on a flat medium, of a selection of material or abstract features on, or in relation to the surface of the Earth, another celestial body, or an imaginary place.
Use for personal narrative accounts of journeys over bodies of water.

Use for dramatic compositions intended for performance as masques, that is, spectacularly lavish and often allegorical entertainments popular in England during the 16th and 17th centuries in predominately aristocratic settings, in which dialogue, song, music, and dance are staged by elaborately costumed performers.
Use for mathematical puzzles, games, or similar entertainments.

CONCEPT.BT: Instructional works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for political pamphlets and broadsides critical of Cardinal Jules Mazarin or his followers published in mid-17th century France.
Use for works not having the contemporary status of a standard. For works having the status of a standard, use "Pharmacopoeias." When in doubt, use "Medical formularies."

CONCEPT.HN: June 2015: term changed from Memorials (Commemorative); items may have been indexed under previous form. In the 1983 edition of Genre Terms, this term was authorized without a parenthetical qualifier, thus items may have been indexed under "Memorials."
CONCEPT.SN: Use for works designed to preserve the memory of a person.
Use for written opinions submitted to an authoritative body, often accompanied by a petition or remonstrance.
Use for manuals containing information on trade routes, market locations, business practices, merchant ethics, etc.

CONCEPT.HN: Changed 1/91. Formerly, "Metamorphic pictures" may have been indexed under "Harlequinades." "Harlequinades (Plays)" is currently used in this thesaurus to index a type of comedy (see above).
CONCEPT.SN: Use for pictures, whether individual or in books, which can be transformed into one or more other pictures by turning, folding, or sliding a section.
Use for commands issued by a military superior.
Use for collections of jokes made by blackface comedians of the 19th- and early 20th-century United States.
CONCEPT.BT: Humorous works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for songs traditionally performed by blackface entertainers, primarily in the 19th and early 20th centuries.
Use for medieval religious narratives based on the legends of saints or martyrs.
CONCEPT.BT: Religious works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for medieval religious plays based on legends of saints or martyrs, or on miracles performed by saints or sacred objects.
Use for books containing all that is said or sung at Mass throughout the year.
Use for allegorical plays of the type which offer discourses in praise of morality between actors representing characters such as Charity, Faith, Death, etc.
Use for catalogs that identify, document and describe works of art, artifacts, and other objects held by a museum.
Use for medieval religious plays based on scriptural incidents.
Use for works containing an account of events, experiences, etc., whether true or fictitious.
CONCEPT.BT: Literary forms (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for official registers of naval officers, listing their rank and the ship to which they are appointed.
Use for poems written in Latin since ca. 1300.

Use for verses in broadside or pamphlet form presented to patrons by trades- and service-people such as watchmen, lamplighters, bakers' boys, etc., around the start of the New Year, often to request a gratuity.
Use for sermons delivered on or around the New Year.
Use for forerunners of newspapers, consisting of more than one leaf, published in the 16th and 17th centuries. For similar items consisting of one leaf, use "Corantos."
Use for periodically issued, brief written reports of news, announcements, and activities of an organization or specific group of people.

Use for publications containing chiefly current or timely topical material, usually intended to appear at regular intervals, weekly or more frequently, not usually designed for ease and permanence of storage.
Use for volumes made up of previously published pamphlets reissued, usually with a collective title page. For volumes bound together for an owner, use Sammelbands (Provenance).
CONCEPT.BT: Conditions of publication (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for humorous or whimsical poetry featuring absurd characters or situations, in which meaning is often subordinated to the sounds and rhythms of the words.
CONCEPT.BT: Humorous works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for books of blank pages, ruled or unruled, intended for taking notes, regardless of whether the book has been used.
Use for a fictional prose narrative shorter than a novel but longer than a short story.
Use for prayers or devotions within the Roman Catholic Church offered on nine consecutive days to request special graces or to express mourning.
Use for rhymed verses or songs for children.
Use for simple, traditional stories told to children.
Use for published notices of a death, usually including a brief biographical account of the deceased.
Use for addresses given on special occasions.
Use for poems written on or intended for a special occasion.
Use for sermons given on special occasions.
Use for literary works whose plots involve witchcraft, voodoo, psychic phenomena, or some other mysterious or secret knowledge or power believed to be attainable only by magic or supernatural means.
Use for lyric poems expressing strong emotions, often in praise of the subject, and usually employing a varied meter and complex structure.
Use for official governmental journals.
Use for works consisting of a section of a larger publication, printed from the same setting of type and issued as a distinct unit.
CONCEPT.BT: Conditions of publication (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.HN: Changed 1/91. Formerly, "Oral histories" may have been indexed as "Oral history."
CONCEPT.SN: Use for oral history interviews only, not for speeches, colloquia, panel discussions, and the like.
Use for British royal orders issued by and with the advice of a privy council; without legal force unless authorized by a parliamentary act.
Use for a sermon given on the occasion of the ordination of a new member of the clergy.
Use for narrative accounts of journeys on overland routes, especially to the American West.
Use for books in which the content is created chiefly with hand-applied paint. For books in which only the binding is painted, use Painted bindings.
Use for short, fictitious stories making comparisons from which moral or spiritual truths are drawn.
CONCEPT.BT: Literary forms (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for formal written requests to Parliament that call for action, usually involving legislation or government administration.
Use for humorous, sometimes satiric, imitations of other works.
CONCEPT.BT: Humorous works (Gathering term; do not assign)
Versions of works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for musical parts.
Use for satires or lampoons intended to be posted in a public place.
Use for lists of people traveling in or on a train, ship, or other conveyance who do not have a role in its operation.
Use for plays representing the Passion of Jesus Christ.
Use for literary or other artistic works created by assembling bits and pieces from other works.
CONCEPT.BT: Humorous works (Gathering term; do not assign)
Versions of works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for plays portraying rural life, especially in an idealized or romantic form, often with shepherds as main characters.
Use for poems portraying rural life, especially in an idealized or romantic form, often with shepherds as main characters.
Use for prose narratives portraying rural life, especially in an idealized or romantic form, often with shepherds as main characters.
CONCEPT.BT: Literary forms (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.CM: Apostrophe not included in term or cross-reference, according to ANSI/NISO z39.19-2005 6.7.2.3.
CONCEPT.SN: Use for works based on the principles or pataphysics (intricate and whimsical nonsense intended as a parody of science).
CONCEPT.BT: Literary forms (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for books of actual patterns.

Use for penmanship or calligraphy instruction books which include instructional text and examples but which do not include blank areas for a pupil’s practice writing. For works which also include blank areas for practice, use "Copy books (Penmanship)."
Use for books consisting solely of samples of handwriting or calligraphy, intended for instruction. For works which also include instructional text, use "Penmanship manuals."

Use for melodramatic fiction featuring romance and adventure published as cheap paperbacks in Great Britain from the late 19th century into the early 20th century. For the American equivalent, use Dime novels.
Use for poems featuring a strong performance element.
Use for serial publications, issued at regular intervals, that contain a mix of articles, editorials, and other short writing.
CONCEPT.BT: Conditions of publication (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for tables that allow determination of the correct day of the week for any given date over a wide range of years.
Use for formal written requests for action made to an individual or body having the authority to grant the request
Use for works having the contemporary status of a standard. When in doubt, use "Medical formularies."
Use for books containing a collection of useful and/or idiomatic words and expressions in a given language, along with their equivalent meanings in another language

CONCEPT.CM: Change made to reconcile form with LCSH and GSAFD.
CONCEPT.HN: 6/99 Changed form of term from "Picaresque fiction" to "Picaresque literature." Formerly, "Picaresque literature" may have been indexed as "Picaresque fiction."
CONCEPT.SN: Use for episodic accounts of the adventures of an engagingly roguish hero.
Use for nautical guides that describe coast lines, harbors, dangers, and aids to navigation.
Use for single-sheet items advertising plays, usually announcing the cast.

CONCEPT.BT: Literary forms (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for novels which have the reader choose from a number of options to develop the story.

CONCEPT.BT: Literary forms (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for collections of contemporary poems by different authors, usually dealing with various topics and primarily published from the 16th through the 18th centuries.
Use for collections of poetry about several places in various parts of the world.
Gathering term; do not use; index under a narrower term.
CONCEPT.BT: Content of work (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for works containing the offices, or forms for sacraments, rites, etc., performed by a pontiff or bishop.

Use for projectionless plane sea charts having equidistant latitudinal markings but no longitudinal markings, featuring the outlines of coasts, and indicating wind directions by rhumb lines, which intersect at wind roses.
Use for placards, often decorative or pictorial, intended to be displayed for purposes of announcement, advertisement, or decoration.
Use for books of personal prayer; they may include selections from liturgical books.
Use for individually issued prayers, not in book form.
Use for official or authoritative statements intended for distribution to news outlets.
Use for lists of the prices of materials or products offered for sale.
Use for books written to instruct beginners in the elementary principles of reading, spelling, or other subjects.
Use for poems that have been awarded a prize.
Use for formal public announcements made by a legal authority.
Use for lists of the events, pieces, performers, speakers, etc., of an entertainment, ceremony, or the like.
Use for plays with manuscript production annotations.
CONCEPT.BT: Versions of works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.HN: 7/00 Scope note and narrower terms "Book prospectuses" and "Company prospectuses" added.
CONCEPT.SN: Use for formal summaries of proposed commercial, literary, or other ventures to solicit investment, purchase, or participation.

CONCEPT.BT: Instructional works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for books containing only the Psalms.
Use "Booksellers' advertisements" rather than this term for examples appearing before the roles of bookseller and publisher were clearly differentiated.
Use "Booksellers' catalogs" rather than this term for examples appearing before the roles of bookseller and publisher were clearly differentiated.
Use for popular fiction dealing with lurid or sensational topics and originally printed on inexpensive paper made from wood pulp.

CONCEPT.DESCRIPTOR: Purpose of work (Gathering term; do not assign)
CONCEPT.SN: Gathering term; do not use; index under a narrower term.
CONCEPT.NT: Humorous works (Gathering term; do not assign)
Instructional works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for toys, contrivances, questions or problems designed for testing ingenuity.
Use for works consisting primarily of a series of questions and answers.
Use for religious dramas of popular origin which were most commonly performed in the churches and public squares of central Italian cities, most common in the 15th century.
Use for textbooks for children consisting of practice reading material generally chosen for moral, literary, or patriotic value.

CONCEPT.BT: Purpose of work (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for works intended for amusement and entertainment that typically involve activities such as puzzles, jokes, riddles, and games.
CONCEPT.BT: Purpose of work (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Gathering term; do not use; index under a narrower term.
CONCEPT.BT: Purpose of work (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for histories of a particular regiment.
Use for authoritative rules and directives designed to control or regulate behavior.
Use for plays that rely heavily on religious themes or are religious in nature.
CONCEPT.BT: Religious works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.DESCRIPTOR: Religious works (Gathering term; do not assign)
CONCEPT.SN: Gathering term; do not use; index under a narrower term.
CONCEPT.BT: Content of work (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for works published surreptitiously or illegally, usually in wartime.
Use for dictionaries in which entries are arranged in a non-standard order, such as by meaning, word endings, or last letter of a word.
Use for intentionally misleading questions or statements, often relying on double meanings or wordplay, that require ingenuity to determine a solution or meaning.
Use for books of instructions and texts for administering the sacraments and various blessings.
Use for books which present road routes, features, or distances; sometimes illustrated.
Use for imitations of Defoe’s Robinson Crusoe.

Use for Renaissance and early modern plays incorporating elements of tragedy and comedy, as well as spectacle, magic and exotic locales, and typically embracing themes of separation and reunion, forgiveness and redemption, and extraordinary adventures set in motion by the complications of love.
Use for medieval and Renaissance tales in prose or verse celebrating the adventures, in love and war, of some hero of chivalry. Do not use for modern romance novels.
CONCEPT.BT: Literary forms (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for novels in which actual people, places, or events are presented under fictitious names.
Use for written requests submitted to a sovereign for the redress of grievances or granting of favor.
Use for early Catholic works containing the priest’s part of the mass, together with prayers for baptisms, blessings, ordinations, and consecrations.
Use for catalogs that list and describe items for sale.
Use for works produced and distributed clandestinely in the Soviet Bloc.
Use for books of actual samples.
Use for works that use humor, especially sarcasm, irony, and exaggeration, in order to criticize people, governments, or institutions as a means of social, political, or artistic commentary.
CONCEPT.BT: Humorous works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for plot outlines of dramatic works.
CONCEPT.BT: Versions of works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for plans or lists of items or events and the times at which they are to occur.
Use for works that feature imagined scientific or technological advances and their impact on society, typically set in the future, on other planets, or in alternate universes.
Use for works intended for amusement and entertainment containing experiments, puzzles, games, and riddles to explain and illustrate principles of science.
Gathering term; do not use; index under a narrower term.
CONCEPT.BT: Content of work (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for graphical, symbolic, or word-based musical notation representing the sounds of all the parts of an ensemble or a work for solo performer or electronic media, arranged vertically so that they can be read at a glance.
Use for albums in which memorabilia, such as photographs, clippings, or ephemera, are affixed or inserted for preservation.

CONCEPT.HN: Changed 6/2016. Formerly, "Screenplays" may have been indexed as "Film scripts" and "Television plays."
CONCEPT.SN: Use for texts of a motion picture or television production indicating the lines to be spoken by each character, with directions for staging the work.
Use for prose works set on or near the ocean, featuring sailors or ships’ officers and the events of their voyages.

CONCEPT.BT: Religious works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for books containing miscellaneous religious rites, whether or not compiled from official liturgical texts; may include hymns.
CONCEPT.BT: Religious works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for publications of all enactments and resolutions of a legislative body passed at a particular session.
Use for a fictional prose narrative shorter than a novel, usually dealing with few characters in a limited setting at a single point in time.

CONCEPT.DESCRIPTOR: Social customs (Gathering term; do not assign)
CONCEPT.SN: Gathering term; do not use; index under a narrower term.
CONCEPT.BT: Content of work (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for single printed sheets containing the lyrics of a song, but not the music.
Use for musical compositions, generally short, containing words. Do not use for large vocal forms, such as opera or oratorio, or for sacred music.
Use for published collections of secular song lyrics, or poems intended to be sung to familiar tunes.
Use for programs distributed to commemorate a specific event, e.g., the dedication of a monument.
Use for books designed to teach elementary spelling and pronunciation, often incorporating religious or moral lessons.
Use for messages from the deceased often transmitted through various means such as talking boards, automatic writing, or mediums.
Use for programs sold at sporting events that contain information about the competition and its participants.

CONCEPT.HN: Term changed 10/2015. Formerly "Stories without words" may have been indexed as "Picture novels."

CONCEPT.SN: Use for works created by students that criticize, challenge, or condemn specific social or political conditions.
Deleted term. Use form "Subscription lists" from RBPUB.
Use for monographic works published by subscription.
CONCEPT.BT: Conditions of publication (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for works of fiction that depict characters striving to rebuild the world after anarchy or the collapse of society by some catastrophic event. For fictional or historic accounts of victims of natural or man-made disasters, as well as accounts of individual or group trauma that are personally written or related by the survivors, use Survivors’ narratives.

CONCEPT.HN: Changed 1/91. Formerly, "Survivors' narratives" may have been indexed as "Survivors’ literature."
CONCEPT.SN: Use for fictional or historic accounts of victims of natural or man-made disasters, as well as accounts of individual or group trauma that are personally written or related by the survivors. For works of fiction that depict characters striving to rebuild the world after anarchy or the collapse of society by some catastrophic event, use Survivalist literature.
Use for brief, written descriptions of the plot of a narrative work such as a novel, play, opera, or poem.
CONCEPT.BT: Versions of works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for books of musical parts so laid out that performers on opposite sides of a table can read them.
Use for books published as the standard work for the formal study of a particular subject.
CONCEPT.BT: Instructional works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for formal written or spoken speeches given on a designated day of thanksgiving and prayer.
Use for official announcements made by a legal authority, declaring a day of thanksgiving and prayer.
Use for sermons given on designated days of thanksgiving and prayer.
Use for printed descriptions of acts, scenes, characters, performers, or other features; usually distributed to audience members at a theater performance
Use for books of synonyms and near-synonyms in a written language, usually arranged conceptually or alphabetically.
Use for novels published in three volumes during the 19th century, especially in Great Britain.
CONCEPT.BT: Conditions of publication (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for miniature volumes containing summaries or abridgments of biblical texts in verse or prose; typically illustrated and produced chiefly for use by children.
CONCEPT.BT: Religious works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for small, oblong comic books, clandestinely published in the U.S. between the 1930s and 1950s and parodying figures of popular culture in explicit sexual situations.

CONCEPT.HN: Term accepted term, 20100116; Candidate term, 20100115 and 200907.
CONCEPT.SN: Use for 19th-century illustrated children's books intended to entertain or amuse, rather than instruct.
Use for sales catalogs directed at people or businesses in a specific trade.
Use for dramatic works involving the downfall or destruction of the protagonist due to character flaws, catastrophe, or reversal of fortune.
Use for plays that combine the qualities of tragedy and comedy, often those which employ a plot suitable for tragedy but end happily.
Use for works that have been put into the words of another language.
CONCEPT.BT: Versions of works (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for descriptive accounts or literary writings by travelers, often presented in narrative form or as memoir.
CONCEPT.BT: Literary forms (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for agreements or contracts, often concerning peace, alliance, economic assistance or commerce, made between two or more states, formally signed by their duly authorized representatives, and usually ratified by their lawmaking authorities.
Use for documents recording the judicial examination and determination of facts and legal issues in a court of law, arising between parties to a civil or criminal action.
Use for printed matter showing the fonts, ornaments, borders, rules, illustrative blocks, etc. that a printer or founder has available.

CONCEPT.BT: Conditions of publication (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.HN: Changed 1/91. Formerly, "Unfinished works" may have been indexed as "Unfinished books."
CONCEPT.SN: Use for works not finished by the author.
CONCEPT.BT: Conditions of publication (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for books conceived and produced as one-of-a-kind.
Use for catalogs issued by institutions of higher education that list courses, names of faculty members, academic calendars, and programs.
Use for works describing or set in an ideal society, especially in regard to laws, government, and social conditions.

CONCEPT.DESCRIPTOR: Versions of works (Gathering term; do not assign)
CONCEPT.SN: Gathering term; do not use; index under a narrower term.
Use for published booklets consisting primarily of views of particular places, events, and activities, sometimes connected by accordion folds.
Use for sermons preached by a bishop, etc., during an official visitation.

Use for devices, whether individual or in books, consisting of one or more movable circles surrounded by other graduated or figured circles and intended for the calculation of astronomical or other data.
CONCEPT.BT: Conditions of publication (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for lists containing the names, addresses, and signatures of registered voters maintained as an official log or record.

Use for fiction whose plots and/or narrative structures deal with the experiences of soldiers or other participants in wartime, and are often based on the activities and events of a particular tour of duty, military unit, armed conflict, or other type of military engagement.
Use for sermons that address the moral and religious implications of war.

Use for works which recount and depict nuptial festivities and events, chiefly of royalty, nobility, or famous persons, and which may also include literary works offered to the principals, such as epithalamia or the Italian "per le nozze."
Use for sermons, typically delivered by the officiant at a wedding ceremony, commenting on the institution of marriage and advising the couple.
Use for works of fiction treating themes of the American West, usually set in the 19th century.
Gathering term; do not use; index under a narrower term.
Use for books which provide instruction in handwriting or penmanship.
Use for works which exhibit fear, dislike or hatred of foreigners, foreign customs, etc.
Use for annual compendia of facts and statistics of the preceding year, frequently limited to a special subject.

Use for inexpensive novels issued in paper boards covered with glazed yellow paper and having a woodcut printed in three colors on the front, usually dating from the late 19th and early 20th centuries.
CONCEPT.BT: Conditions of publication (Gathering term; do not assign)

CONCEPT.SN: Use for independent self-publications, periodical or monographic, usually inexpensively produced and with small circulation, covering any of a wide range of topics.
CONCEPT.BT: Conditions of publication (Gathering term; do not assign)
